questions.text: CSF otorrhea can occur in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Temporal Bone fracture

 

CSF otorrhea is associated with Longitudinal Temporal Bone fracture.

 

Temporal bone fractures can be of types:

 

 

 

Battle’s sign is associated with temporal bone fracture.

 

 

Cribriform plate damage can lead to CSF rhinorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TM rupture due to trauma: While traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane may occur, it does not typically result in CSF otorrhea unless associated with a temporal bone fracture.

 

Option B. Stab injury in the eye: Unlikely to cause CSF otorrhea directly unless there is extensive cranial trauma involving the skull base.

 

Option C. Cribriform plate fracture: More commonly associated with CSF rhinorrhea (leakage of CSF from the nose) due to its location and relationship to the nasal cavity and sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF otorrhea is a serious condition often linked with fractures of the temporal bone. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent complications and promote effective healing. Monitoring for signs of infection or persistent leakage is essential, as these may necessitate more aggressive interventions.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with the defect seen in the image below. Identify the condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

 

Omphalocele is characterized by the presence of a sac enclosing the protruding abdominal organs, which herniate into the base of the umbilical cord.

 

The image depicts a newborn with a congenital abdominal wall defect characterized by the protrusion of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes. This condition is known as an omphalocele.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the intestines protrude through a hole in the abdominal wall, typically to the right of the umbilicus. Unlike omphalocele, in gastroschisis, the intestines are not covered by a sac and are exposed directly to the amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: Persistent vitellointestinal duct refers to a remnant of the yolk stalk (vitelline duct) that can cause various intestinal anomalies but does not present as a protrusion of abdominal contents covered by a sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes.

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure
The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation

questions.text: The true statement among the following is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

 

Losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker. It binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. It is also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates platelet aggregation. All ARBs are avoided in moderate to severe renal impairment due to risk of development of hyperkalemia. Most ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic impairment also except LEO (Safe in Liver disease are Eprosartan and Olmesartan)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure: Like all the ARBs, telmisartan is avoided in severe renal disease. Further, telmisartan is excreted by biliary secretion. So, dose of telmisartan should be reduced in mild to moderate hepatic failure. 

 

Option B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure: Irbesartan is avoided in both severe renal and hepatic disease.

 

Option C. The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure: Olmesartan require dose adjustment in severe renal failure. However, olmesartan and eprosartan do not require dose adjustment even in severe liver failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All ARBs should be avoided in moderate to severe renal disease due to risk of hyperkalemia. Except Olmesartan and Eprosartan, all other ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic disease also. Losartan has additional antiplatelet action by acting as TXA2 receptor antagonist.

questions.text: Identify the structure which is responsible for elevation and is supplied by the nerve emergency from the structure shown in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Risorius

 

Explanation:

 

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve, resulting in the marked elevation. The image depicts the floor of the fourth ventricle, as well as the facial colliculus.

 

 

The facial colliculus is a raised area on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brainstem, and it is associated with the motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The facial nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, including the risorius muscle, which is one of the muscles that can cause elevation of the corner of the mouth in smiling. Therefore, the structure that is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation would be the risorius muscle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral rectus: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

 

Option B. Superior oblique: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). This muscle is responsible for raising the upper eyelid (levator means "elevator"), allowing you to open your eyes.

 

The oculomotor nerve also innervates several other muscles that control eye movement and pupil constriction, making it an important cranial nerve for eye function

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risorius muscle, responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth laterally and aiding in expressions like smiling, is innervated by the facial nerve.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with tuberculosis. As part of his treatment plan, he is prescribed a combination of antitubercular drugs. While counseling him on the drug regimen, you explain the mechanisms of action of each drug. Which of the following combinations of statements accurately describe the mechanisms of some of the drugs used in treating tuberculosis? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis
  2. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer
  3. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis
  4. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

1. lsoniazid - INH is activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.

 

4. Bedaquiline - Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Pyrazinamide - Possess the best sterilizing activity (can kill slow growing bacteria) and makes the medium sterile. Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is not an enzyme inducer.

 

3. Rifampicin - Act by inhibiting RNA polymerase of mycobacteria by binding to its β-subunit. It thus inhibits transcription. Uses of Rifampicin are:

 

  • Tuberculosis
  • Leprosy
  • DOC for Brucella (doxycycline + rifampicin)
  • Effective against Gram positive bacteria (including MRSA)
  • Effective against Gram negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas)
  • It was used for prophylaxis of meningococcus meningitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme.
  • Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old post-menopausal female came with persistent back ache, not responding to conservative treatment. She has a history of heavy weight lifting 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking and starts radiating down her legs within 100m range of walking, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs. Most probable diagnosis is? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lumbar canal stenosis

 

LUMBAR CANAL STENOSIS

 

  • Lumbar spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal canal, compressing the nerves travelling through the lower back into the legs.
  • While it may affect younger patients, due to developmental causes, it is more often a degenerative condition that affects people who are typically age 60 and older.
  • Narrowing of the spinal canal usually occurs slowly, over many years or decades.
  • Degenerative spondylosis is a significant etiology of lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • The discs become less spongy with aging, resulting in loss of disc height, and may cause bulging of the hardened disc into the spinal canal.
  • Bone spurs may also occur and ligaments may thicken.
  • All of these can contribute to narrowing of the central canal and may or may not produce symptoms.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis is another cause of lumbar spinal stenosis. When degenerative changes of the spine occur, the pars interarticularis can be fractured, and the resulting instability can lead to forward translation of the vertebra.  Sufficient anterior slippage of one vertebra on the next vertebral segment can narrow the spinal canal, leading to stenosis.
  • When the lateral recess and neural foramen are stenosed, symptoms of lumbar radiculopathy may also present.
  • Classification (anatomic):
    • Central stenosis: caused by hypertrophied ligamentaum flavum anteriorly and bulging disc posteriorly with consequent thecal sac compression
    • Lateral recess stenosis: due to facet joint arthropathy with overgrowth of the superior articular facet and osteophyte formation. This results in compression of the descending nerve roots.
    • Foraminal stenosis: due to loss of disc height, foraminal disc protrusion, or osteophyte formation with resultant compression of the exiting nerve root.
    • Extraforaminal stenosis: due to far lateral disc herniation again with resultant exiting nerve root compression 
  • Symptoms may be due to inflammation, compression of the nerve(s) or both.
  • Such symptoms may include:
    • Pain, weakness or numbness in the legs, calves or buttocks, exacerbated by prolonged ambulation, standing, and with lumbar extension, and is relieved by forward flexion and rest.
    • Neurogenic claudication is an important feature. Symptoms are bilateral, but usually asymmetric. Low back pain, numbness, and tingling are present.
    • Cramping in the calves with walking, requiring frequent short rests to walk a distance
    • Pain radiating into one or both thighs and legs, similar to the lay term “sciatica”
    • In rare cases, loss of motor functioning of the legs, loss of normal bowel or bladder function
    • Pain may improve with bending forward, sitting or lying down.
    • Walking upstairs being easier than walking downstairs, as the back is forward flexed with stairs climbing.
    • If patients present with new-onset bowel or bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, bilateral lower extremity weakness, and/or increased lower extremity, the patient may have developed cauda equina or conus medullaris syndromes. 
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis and degenerative scoliosis are two conditions that may be associated with lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis (slippage of one vertebra over another) is caused by osteoarthritis of the facet joints. Most commonly, it involves the L4 slipping over the L5 vertebra. It is usually treated with the same non-surgical (“conservative”) and surgical methods as lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Investigations:
    • MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the modality of choice for lumbar spinal stenosis, and CT myelography is an option when MRI is contraindicated.
    • Anteroposterior spinal canal diameters of less than 10 mm are also frequently used for the diagnosis of lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Treatment:
    • Management for lumbar spinal stenosis aims at reducing symptoms and improving functional status. 
    • Conservative treatment is the first-line treatment for this condition. 
    • Conservative treatment options include physical therapy, oral anti-inflammatory medications, and epidural steroid injections.
    • The most frequently performed surgical procedure is a laminectomy (Wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression). This is usually indicated in cases of ongoing pain despite conservative measures for 3-6 months and where there is progressive neurologic deterioration e.g. motor weakness, bowel and/or bladder dysfunction.
    • Laminectomy with fusion (wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression with instrumented fusion) is indicated when further stability is required, which is done in patients with concurrent segmental instability e.g. spondylolisthesis (degenerative or isthmic) or degenerative scoliosis.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Vertebral osteoporotic compression fracture. These are very common fragility fractures of the spine that affect up to 50% of people over 80 years old. The patient complains of pain localized to area of fracture. There is focal tenderness or pain with deep palpation of spinous process. Radiographs will show loss of anterior, middle, or posterior vertebral height by 20% or at least 4mm. Treatment is usually non-operative. If the fracture is less than five days old, calcitonin can be used for four weeks to decrease pain. Bisphosphonates can be given to prevent future risk of fragility fractures. Some patients may benefit from an extension orthosis. Surgical options may include vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty, surgical decompression and stabilization.

 

 

Option B. PIVD. A herniated disc in the spine is a condition during which a nucleus pulposus is displaced from intervertebral space. It is a common cause of back pain. Herniated disc pain often presents with burning sensation, and may radiate into the lower extremity. Furthermore, in more severe cases, there can be associated with weakness or sensation changes. The disc prolapse can be very painful. Within a few weeks, most cases heal. In many instances, it does not cause that patient any pain. They are often seen on MRI of asymptomatic patients. The initial treatment should be conservative, unless a patient has severe neurological compromise. Surgery is usually the last resort. Physical therapy is the key for most patients.

 

 

Option D. Isthmic spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis occurs when there is an anterior translation or “slippage” of one vertebral body relative to its caudal vertebral body. In most cases, symptoms associated with spondylolisthesis are chronic.  The primary symptom of chronic spondylolisthesis is back pain, with or without leg pain. Isthmic spondylolisthesis refers to a defect in the pars interarticularis that results in anterior subluxation over time, most commonly at L5-S1 followed by L4-5. The resulting anterior subluxation can produce back pain, central canal stenosis, and lateral recess or foraminal stenosis. The most common etiology for isthmic spondylolisthesis is instability of unilateral or bilateral pars interarticularis. The most common symptom of presentation is low back pain, which may be mechanical in nature, depressed deep tendon reflexes, positive straight leg signs, and diminished sensations. Isthmic spondylolisthesis with low back pain should initially be managed conservatively. Surgical treatment options consist of decompression of the neural elements alone versus decompression with internal fixation for bony fusion to prevent further subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A back pain that worsens on walking and radiates down the legs within 100m of walking, and that does not occur on climbing up the stairs, is suggestive of lumbar canal stenosis where the pain relieves on forward bending the trunk, as in climbing the stairs.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hoffman’s degradation? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cis-atracurium

 

Atracurium and Cis-atracurium undergo Hoffman’s degradation, a process independent of renal and hepatic function. These break down at physiological pH and temperature, making them a suitable neuromuscular blocking agents for patients with renal or hepatic impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mivacurium: Mivacurium is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase, not through Hoffman's degradation.

 

Option C. Pancuronium: Pancuronium is primarily metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, not by Hoffman's degradation.

 

Option D. Vecuronium: Vecuronium is also metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, and does not undergo Hoffman’s degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cis-atracurium undergoes Hoffman’s degradation, a process independent of renal and hepatic function, making it suitable for use in patients with renal or hepatic impairment.

questions.text: Identify this condition. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condyloma acuminata

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows anogenital warts, which are characteristic of condyloma acuminata. These warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and present as rough-surfaced papules and plaques in the anogenital region. The warts can vary in size and shape and are typically painless but can cause discomfort due to their location.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option  B. Herpes genitalis: This condition presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. These vesicles can rupture to form polycyclic erosions.

 

 

Option  C. Condyloma lata: Associated with secondary syphilis, condyloma lata manifests as broad-based, moist, eroded, flat papules and plaques in the genital area.

 

 

Option  D. Hemorrhoids: These are swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus, presenting as bluish swollen lumps that can cause pain and bleeding. The image does not depict the typical appearance of hemorrhoids.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata presents as rough-surfaced papules and plaques in the anogenital area, characteristic of anogenital warts caused by HPV. Recognizing the appearance of these lesions is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caspase – 1

 

Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1.

 

Pyroptosis is a type of controlled cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis that is mediated by IL-1. It takes part in the removal of microbially and necrotically affected cells.

 

Caspase-1 and the inflammasome complex are both activated.

 

  • IL-1 production causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Caspase - 3, C. Caspase - 9 and  D. Caspase – 8: These caspases are primarily involved in the apoptosis pathway, not in the activation of IL-1. Caspase-3 and caspase-9 are part of the apoptotic cascade that leads to programmed cell death without inflammation. Caspase-8 is involved in extrinsic apoptosis signaling and can overlap with inflammatory pathways but does not directly activate IL-1.

 

Educational objective:

 

Caspase-1 is critical for the activation of IL-1, directly linking it to the inflammatory response and distinguishing it from other caspases primarily involved in apoptotic pathways. This mechanism underscores the specific role of the inflammasome and pyroptosis in immune defense and inflammatory regulation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with visual acuity of 6/18, which improves upon performing the pinhole test. During the examination, the presence of fibrosis in the lens nucleus is noted, and his near vision displays improvement. Based on these findings, what is the refractive error he is presenting with? (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Index myopia

 

The improvement in near vision of a presbyopic patient is referred to as the "second sight phenomenon", given in the clinical picture, which is suggestive of index myopia. It manifests as index myopia as a result of nuclear cataract production.

 

MYOPIA - Parallel rays of light are brought into focus in front of the retina when accommodation is at rest. This is also called short sightedness or near sightedness.

 

Types –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Index hypermetropia: This would involve a decrease in the refractive index, leading to farsightedness, which is not consistent with the patient's symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. Presbyopia: This is an age-related condition causing difficulty in near vision due to the lens losing its flexibility. It does not explain the improvement in near vision or the findings of lens fibrosis.

 

Option D. Axial myopia: This is due to an increase in the length of the eyeball and would not be associated with the fibrosis of the lens nucleus or the improvement in near vision seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Index myopia is characterized by an increase in the refractive index of the lens nucleus, often associated with nuclear sclerosis in cataracts, and can result in the "second sight phenomenon," where near vision temporarily improves

choices.text: Raised JVP with normal waveform

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent a wave

 

The patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse, which is highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of coordinated atrial contractions, leading to an irregularly irregular ventricular response. This irregularity can be confirmed by a pulse deficit, where the heart rate (as measured by auscultation) is higher than the pulse rate (as felt at the periphery).

 

In atrial fibrillation, the chaotic atrial activity results in the absence of effective atrial contraction. This leads to the absence of a wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP), as a wave is generated by atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent p wave: While it is true that atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of P waves on the ECG, the question specifically asks about the JVP finding, not the ECG finding.

 

Option C. Cannon a wave: Cannon a waves are typically seen in conditions where there is atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block. They are not associated with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform: Raised JVP can occur in various conditions, but the presence of a normal waveform would not be consistent with atrial fibrillation, where the a wave is absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella/ Salmonella.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

  • Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
  • Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.
  • Alkaline peptone water (Option-B) - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of anaerobic bacteria, not typically involved in cases of dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This is used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases suspected of cholera, which typically presents with watery diarrhea rather than bloody stools.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: It is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: Which tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus on inversion of the foot? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibialis

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is located behind the medial malleolus, and it is palpable when the foot is inverted. This tendon is essential for supporting the arch of the foot and plays a significant role in foot inversion. During the movement of foot inversion, the posterior tibialis tendon becomes more prominent and easier to palpate behind the medial malleolus, which is the bony prominence on the inner side of the ankle.

 

The posterior tibialis tendon inserts on the navicular bone (sometimes referred to as the scaphoid of the foot). This tendon’s attachment helps maintain the foot's arch and aids in foot inversion.

 

Note - Kohler disease is a rare bone disorder that causes osteochondritis of the navicular bone in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibialis: The anterior tibialis tendon is located on the anterior side of the ankle and foot. It is responsible for dorsiflexion (lifting the foot upward) and does not pass behind the medial malleolus, making it unpalpable in this area during inversion.

 

Option B. Extensor hallucis brevis: The extensor hallucis brevis is involved in extending the big toe. It does not run behind the medial malleolus and is located on the dorsum of the foot, so it is unrelated to the action of inversion or palpation behind the medial malleolus.

 

Option C. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon extends the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is found on the anterior aspect of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and is not palpable during inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot and inserts on the navicular bone.

questions.text: In screening for diabetes in pregnancy, the dose of oral glucose load given is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 75g

 

Explanation:

 

For screening and diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is commonly used. The standard protocol involves a 75-gram oral glucose load.

 

Protocol for 75-gram OGTT:

 

International Guidelines: According to the International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG):

 

  • The test is performed after an overnight fast.
  • A fasting blood sample is taken.
  • The woman is then given a 75-gram oral glucose load.
  • Blood samples are taken at 1 hour and 2 hours after the glucose load.
  • Diagnostic thresholds:
    • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
    • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
    • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL

 

A diagnosis of GDM is made if any one of these values is met or exceeded.

 

DIPSI Criteria (India):

 

This method can be used irrespective of the prandial state (whether the woman is fasting or not).

 

  • A 75-gram oral glucose load is given.
  • A blood sample is taken 2 hours later.
  • A 2-hour plasma glucose value ≥ 140 mg/dL indicates GDM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50g: Used in the 50-gram glucose challenge test, which is a preliminary screening test, but not diagnostic.

 

Option C. 100g: Used in the 3-hour OGTT, which is less commonly used now compared to the 75-gram test.

 

Option D. 150g: Not used for GDM screening or diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

The current standard for screening and diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus is the 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

 

AMI refers to the sudden onset of intestinal hypoperfusion, which can be caused by an arterial embolism, arterial thrombosis, or venous thrombosis. Given the patient's history of ischemic heart disease (IHD), he is at risk for cardiac emboli. The symptoms described, such as severe diffuse abdominal pain out of proportion to the clinical findings with an absence of bowel sounds and vomiting, are typical for AMI. The irregular rhythm (possibly atrial fibrillation) increases the risk of embolization, leading to acute mesenteric ischemia, typically involving SMA leading to massive intestinal gangrene if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute severe pancreatitis: While this can cause severe abdominal pain, it typically presents with pain radiating to the back and is often associated with a history of alcohol intake or gallstone disease. The absence of bowel sounds might be seen, but other signs like fever, lack of increased amylase or lipase levels, and the nature of pain differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option B. Ruptured aortic aneurysm: This is a life-threatening condition that presents with sudden, severe pain. While it can cause hypotension, the nature of pain and other clinical findings (e.g., palpable pulsatile abdominal mass) can differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer perforation: A perforated peptic ulcer can lead to sudden, severe abdominal pain. However, this typically presents with a board-like rigid abdomen due to the spillage of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to acute peritonitis. This is different from the "soft" abdomen described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.

 

The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.

 

Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: Artery supplying near marked structure is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior interventricular artery

 

The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending artery (LAD), supplies the anterior portion of the interventricular septum. This artery runs along the anterior interventricular groove and is critical in providing blood to the front part of the heart, including the septum and the left ventricle. The LAD is often referred to as the "widowmaker" artery because blockage of this artery can lead to severe myocardial infarction, which is often fatal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left circumflex artery: This artery supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle but does not supply the anterior interventricular septum.

 

Option B. Left marginal artery: This artery branches off the circumflex artery and supplies the left ventricle's lateral wall, but it does not supply the interventricular septum.

 

Option D. Posterior interventricular artery: This artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum but not the anterior portion. It runs in the posterior interventricular groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and is critical for heart function, making it a key vessel in coronary circulation.

choices.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than Inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is equal to Inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is greater than Inulin clearance

questions.text: Which of the following is true? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Creatinine clearance is greater than Inulin clearance

 

Explanation:

 

Creatinine clearance slightly overestimates GFR compared to inulin clearance. This is because, in addition to being filtered at the glomerulus, a small amount of creatinine is secreted by the renal tubules, resulting in a higher clearance value.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creatinine Clearance is Lesser than Inulin Clearance: Creatinine clearance is often slightly higher than inulin clearance. While inulin is exclusively filtered at the glomerulus and not reabsorbed or secreted, creatinine, although primarily filtered, is also slightly secreted by the renal tubules. This secretion leads to a slightly higher clearance rate compared to inulin.

 

Option B. Creatinine Clearance is Equal to Inulin Clearance: Although creatinine clearance is frequently used as a practical estimate of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), it is not exactly equal to inulin clearance. Inulin clearance is a more accurate measure of GFR as it is neither reabsorbed nor secreted, whereas creatinine is slightly secreted.

 

Option D. None of the Above: The correct statement is that creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance, as explained above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine and inulin are both substances that are used to measure kidney function. Creatinine is a waste product of muscle metabolism, while inulin is a plant-derived polysaccharide that is not normally produced by the human body.

 

Creatinine clearance is a measure of the rate at which creatinine is cleared from the blood by the kidneys, while inulin clearance is a measure of the rate at which inulin is cleared from the blood by the kidneys. In theory, the clearance rates of these two substances should be equal, as they are both freely filtered by the glomerulus (the filtering unit of the kidney) and are not reabsorbed or secreted by the tubules but in practice, creatinine clearance is generally slightly higher due to the tubular secretion of creatinine and the possibility of incomplete urine collection during the clearance test.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 574

questions.text: This child is suffering from: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of malnutrition, primarily due to protein deficiency. It's characterized by edema, an enlarged liver, and often a distended abdomen, along with changes in hair and skin color. The presence of edema is a distinguishing feature from marasmus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marasmus: Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by energy deficiency. It typically presents with extreme muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat. Children with marasmus appear emaciated with very little muscle and fat tissue.

 

Option C. Von Gierke’s Disease: This is a type of glycogen storage disease caused by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase. It primarily affects the liver and kidneys, leading to symptoms like severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). It doesn't typically present with the same symptoms as malnutrition-related conditions like marasmus or kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Nephrotic Syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney disorder that causes the body to excrete too much protein in the urine. Key features include severe edema, particularly around the eyes and in the lower extremities, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. While edema is present, it differs from the edema seen in kwashiorkor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake.
  • C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema (swollen belly and legs) due to decreased serum albumin levels.
  • Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.

 

Treatment – diet adequate in calories and protein.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 532-533

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early-onset preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Early-onset preeclampsia:
    • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia.
    • Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers.
    • Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • Predictors of Preeclampsia:
    • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP):
      • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
    • Biophysical Markers:
      • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
    • Biochemical Markers:
      • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF.
      • Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
    • Anti-angiogenic Factors:
      • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Late-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler is more predictive of early-onset rather than late-onset preeclampsia.

 

Option C. Fetal growth restriction: While fetal growth restriction can be associated with preeclampsia, the uterine artery Doppler specifically predicts early-onset preeclampsia rather than fetal growth restriction alone.

 

Option D. Placenta accreta: Uterine artery Doppler is not used to detect placenta accreta. Placenta accreta is typically diagnosed through ultrasound or MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks gestation can predict early-onset preeclampsia by identifying raised pulsatility index (PI) and notching of the uterine artery waveform.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td vaccine

 

In the national immunization schedule, the TT/Td vaccine is given to children at 10 years & 16 years of age as part of the school immunization program.

 

Additional Information

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles Vaccine can be given till 5 years of age.

 

Option B. Rotavirus vaccines can be given till 12 years of age.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccine can be given till 1 year of age.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

National Immunisation schedule (2023-24):

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Usually a sequela of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis.
  • Causative organism: staphylococcus aureus
  • Presenting Complaints:
    • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom.
    • The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
    • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
    • Discharge: Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus.
    • There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
    • Pain: Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations.
    • Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever etc., are present only during acute exacerbations.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
    • Patchy sclerosis
    • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
    • Sequestrum: It is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. It is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues. It acts as nidus of infection and is the most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis. A chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge may be seen.
    • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. It is usually obvious by the end of 2nd week.
    • If infection persists, pus and tiny sequestrated spicules of bone may continue to discharge from the perforations called cloacae.

 

 

  • Rim sign is seen on MRI.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical.
    • Paprika sign is the appearance of the live bone after removal of sequestrum.
       

 

  • Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.
  • Various surgical options are:
    • Sequestrectomy
    • Saucerisation
    • Curettage
    • Excision of an infected bone
    • Amputation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Stress fracture of tibia. A tibial shaft stress fracture is an overuse injury where normal or abnormal bone is subjected to repetitive stress, resulting in microfractures. It is commonly seen in runners. There is linear microfracture in trabecular bone from repetitive loading. The patient have pain directly over the fracture which initially worsen after running. Diagnosis can often be made on radiographs alone but MRI studies should be obtained in patients with normal radiographs with a high degree of suspicion for stress fracture. Lateral x-ray shows dreaded black line anteriorly, endosteal thickening, periosteal reaction with cortical thickening. Treatment is activity restriction with protected weight-bearing in most cases. Surgical intramedullary nailing is recommended in the presence of an anterior tibia tension-sided stress fracture ("dreaded black line").

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological image shown in the question and the clinical symptoms described are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the detection of monkeypox? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PCR

 

The standard technique for the detection of monkeypox is Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). PCR is a molecular technique used to amplify and detect the DNA of the orthopoxvirus, which includes the monkeypox virus. This method is highly sensitive and specific, making it the preferred choice for diagnosing monkeypox. PCR can detect the presence of orthopoxvirus DNA in various clinical specimens, providing a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While an IgM ELISA test can detect antibodies against monkeypox and can become positive about 5 to 8 days after infection, it is not the primary method for initial detection of the virus itself.

 

Option C. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not typically used for the detection of viral DNA in the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Option D. Hemagglutination: This assay is used to detect the ability of viruses to agglutinate red blood cells. It is not commonly used for the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective and standard method for the detection of monkeypox is PCR, which detects the DNA of the orthopoxvirus in clinical specimens.

questions.text: Which of the following samples is considered the best for detecting lead poisoning? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood

 

Explanation:

 

Lead poisoning primarily affects the synthesis of heme by inhibiting three crucial enzymes: Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), Coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and Ferrochelatase. This inhibition leads to the accumulation of their immediate precursors: aminolevulinic acid, coproporphyrinogen, and protoporphyrin.

 

Due to this, lead poisoning can present with various symptoms, including anemia, punctate basophilia (bluish granules in RBCs), and elevated levels of these precursors. The most reliable diagnostic measure for lead poisoning is the blood lead level (> 70 μg/dl), which correlates best with adverse clinical symptoms and the toxicity profile of lead.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hair: While lead can be detected in hair, it does not correlate as well with the severity of poisoning or clinical symptoms as blood levels do.

 

Option C. Saliva: Saliva is not a standard sample for lead detection and does not provide reliable results.

 

Option D. Urine: Though urine can show lead excretion, it is not as reliable as blood levels for correlating with toxicity and clinical manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood lead levels are the most reliable and best indicator for detecting lead poisoning, correlating well with clinical symptoms and toxicity.

 

Laboratory diagnosis of Lead Poisoning –

 

  • Porphyrinuria due to coproporphyrin III.
  • Blood lead level > 70–100 μg/dl.
  • Protoporphyrin  > 35 μg/dl.
  • Urine lead level > 0.15–0.3 mg/l.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

 

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

 

The cylindrical power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

 

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
 

 

For example, for spherical power is +2 and cylindrical power is +3,

Spherical equivalent = +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

 

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK: should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

 

Option D. Implantable Collamer lens: is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following IV anesthetics acts on an NMDA receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketamine

 

Ketamine is an intravenous anesthetic that acts as an antagonist at the NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor. NMDA receptors are involved in the excitatory neurotransmission in the brain, particularly in the processes of synaptic plasticity and memory function. Ketamine inhibits these receptors, leading to a dissociative anesthesia characterized by analgesia, amnesia, and altered sensory perception without complete loss of consciousness. This unique mechanism of action makes ketamine distinct from other commonly used IV anesthetics.

 

Note - The inhalational agents that act on the NMDA receptor as antagonists are xenon and nitrous oxide

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol acts primarily as a GABA agonist, enhancing the activity of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA at the GABA-A receptor, leading to sedation and anesthesia. It does not act on NMDA receptors.

 

Option C. Thiopentone sodium: Thiopentone, a barbiturate, also works as a GABA agonist, similar to propofol. It does not affect NMDA receptors.

 

Option D. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that acts on the GABA-A receptor as well, increasing the inhibitory effects of GABA. Like propofol and thiopentone, it does not interact with NMDA receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine is unique among IV anesthetics for its action as an NMDA receptor antagonist, leading to its characteristic dissociative anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

 

Cholangiocarcinoma, a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts, has several well-established risk factors. These include chronic inflammatory conditions like primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), parasitic infections such as Opisthorchis viverrini, and congenital conditions like Caroli's disease. However, while Hepatitis C is recognized as a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma, Hepatitis B is not commonly associated with this type of cancer. The confusion often arises because Hepatitis B is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, another type of liver cancer, but not specifically for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caroli's disease: Caroli's disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the dilation of the bile ducts and is associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): PSC is a chronic liver disease that causes inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts. It is a well-known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Opisthorchis V. (Opisthorchis viverrini): Opisthorchis viverrini, a liver fluke, is a parasitic infection known to increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, especially in endemic regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B infection is not a recognized risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Instead, focus on chronic inflammatory conditions, parasitic infections, and certain congenital disorders as key risk factors for this type of cancer.

choices.text: Trinucleotide mutation in FMR-1 gene
Mental retardation
Large everted ears

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Micro-orchidism

 

Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.

 

Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. This expansion leads to a deficiency in the FMRP protein, which is important for neural development and function. Males with fragile X syndrome often have macro-orchidism, which can be observed during childhood and becomes more apparent during puberty. Other physical features of fragile X syndrome may include a long and narrow face, prominent forehead and chin, and large ears that are often everted. Intellectual disability and behavioral problems are also common features of the syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT shows SAH. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

 

Explanation:

 

The description of the "worst headache of his life" is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). When an initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) confirms SAH, the next step is to identify the source of bleeding, which is most commonly an aneurysm.

 

CT Angiography is the preferred next step to localize the aneurysm and plan further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lumbar puncture: Indicated if the initial CT scan is negative and there is still suspicion of SAH, to check for xanthochromia.

 

Option C. MRI brain: Not the initial choice for acute SAH diagnosis or aneurysm localization.

 

Option D. V-P shunt: Used for hydrocephalus management, not for immediate SAH diagnosis and management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT, the next step is CT Angiography to identify and localize the source of bleeding.

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The histological image shows a lot of pink areas, indicative of necrosis, and an inflammatory infiltrate. These features are suggestive of caseous necrosis, surrounded by a ring of lymphocytes, which is characteristic of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis often affects the cervical lymph nodes, leading to their enlargement and caseous necrosis, commonly referred to as "matting" of the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect. Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas and commonly affects the lungs and hilar lymph nodes, not typically the cervical lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Incorrect. This condition would show Langerhans cells (which have a characteristic appearance) and is not associated with the caseous necrosis seen in the image.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. Hodgkin lymphoma presents with Reed Sternberg cells and does not show caseous necrosis. Although Hodgkin lymphoma can cause cervical lymph node enlargement, it does not fit the granulomatous inflammation pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

 

Histological Hallmarks of TB in Lymph Nodes:

 

  • Caseating granulomas (granulomas with central necrosis)
  • Surrounding epithelioid histiocytes, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes
  • Necrosis is a key differentiator from sarcoidosis (which has non-caseating granulomas)

questions.text: In the management of a thyroid storm, a critical and life-threatening condition due to an excess of thyroid hormone, a variety of medications are used to control the symptoms and the overactive thyroid. Which of the following drugs is not typically used in the treatment of thyroid storm? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspirin

 

Aspirin is avoided in thyroid storm because it can displace thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially increasing the levels of active thyroid hormone in the blood and exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options

 

Thyroid storm is a severe hypermetabolic state caused by an excessive release of thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis). The standard treatment includes:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used to manage the sympathetic symptoms of thyrotoxicosis like tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. It also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to the more active T3.

 

Option B. Lugol’s Iodine: Lugol's Iodine is given to decrease the synthesis and release of thyroid hormones. The high iodine content temporarily inhibits the synthesis of thyroid hormones (the Wolff-Chaikoff effect) and blocks their release into the circulation.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is preferred for fever control in thyroid storm. It does not have the anti-inflammatory properties that might interfere with thyroid hormone levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is not used in the treatment of thyroid storm because it can increase free thyroid hormone levels by displacing thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came with early satiety, massive splenomegaly, petechiae, and bleeding gums. Her hemoglobin was 8 gm/dl and TLC was 85,000/mm3. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CML

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are highly suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

 

The patient, a 20-year-old female, presents with early satiety, which can be attributed to the massive splenomegaly. An enlarged spleen can compress the stomach, leading to a feeling of early satiety. Massive splenomegaly is a characteristic feature of CML, resulting from the infiltration of the spleen by leukemic cells.

 

The presence of petechiae and bleeding gums indicates thrombocytopenia, which is a common finding in CML patients. Thrombocytopenia can be caused by the decreased production of platelets due to the crowding out of normal hematopoietic cells by the leukemic cells in the bone marrow.

 

The patient's hemoglobin level of 8 gm/dl suggests anemia, another common finding in CML. Anemia in CML can be due to the ineffective erythropoiesis caused by the abnormal proliferation of myeloid cells.

 

The most striking finding is the markedly elevated total leukocyte count (TLC) of 85,000/mm3, which is highly indicative of CML. In CML, there is a characteristic uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells, leading to a significant increase in the white blood cell count.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): ALL is more common in pediatric patients and typically presents with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and bone tenderness. The extremely high TLC and massive splenomegaly are more suggestive of CML than ALL.

 

Option B. AML (Acute Myelogenous Leukemia): AML can present with gum hyperplasia, the presence of myeloblasts with granular cytoplasm, or Auer rods (rod-shaped or needle-shaped crystals). The chronic nature of the presentation and the massive splenomegaly are more consistent with CML.

 

 

Option D. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is more common in older adults and typically presents with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and a high lymphocyte count. The high TLC with myeloid predominance and the absence of significant lymphadenopathy make CML a more likely diagnosis than CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) should be strongly suspected in a patient presenting with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance.

 

The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, is the hallmark genetic abnormality in CML.

choices.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter
The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both a and b

 

Rape on Children:

 

In rape of a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because of two reasons:

 

  • Vaginal opening is very small, hence penetration very difficult. Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. And as such, only redness and tenderness of vulva may be caused.
  • Hymen is deeply situated, hence even if some penetration occurred, it is not ruptured.

 

Also, in a child, there may be no signs or very few signs of general violence since the child has no idea of the act and is also unable to offer resistance.

 

However, in rare cases of great violence, the penis may be forcibly introduced, causing rupture of the vaginal vault, Hymen and associated visceral injuries. In this case the injuries will be more severe than adults and such injuries might result in death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to treat hypertension and edema. It is not specifically known to delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. While it helps in managing blood pressure, it does not have the protective renal effects seen with other medications listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: These drugs, such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been shown to provide renal protection by reducing the progression of kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by decreasing glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to osmotic diuresis and reduced glomerular hyperfiltration.

 

Option B. Finerenone: This is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA) approved for the treatment of chronic kidney disease in type 2 diabetes. It helps to reduce albuminuria and slows the progression of renal disease.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs, such as losartan and valsartan, are well-known for their renal protective effects. They help reduce proteinuria and slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy by blocking the effects of angiotensin II on the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: Which value is derived in ABG?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, pH, pO2 (partial pressure of oxygen), and pCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) are measured directly by the ABG machine.

 

Bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured but is derived using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation. The equation relates the pH, pCO2, and bicarbonate concentration, enabling the calculation of bicarbonate from the directly measured values of pH and pCO2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. pH: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an electrode sensitive to hydrogen ions.

 

Option B. pO2: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an oxygen-sensitive electrode.

 

Option C. pCO2: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using a carbon dioxide-sensitive electrode.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is the value that is derived, not directly measured, using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity and history of recurrent tooth abscess. On lab investigation, his serum calcium was normal, serum phosphorus was normal/reduced, serum PTH was normal, and ALP was increased. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A)  Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The key finding in this case is the normal PTH level. In metabolic bone disorders like rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) is often elevated, but in hypophosphatemic rickets, PTH remains normal. The patient also has normal/reduced serum phosphorus, which is another critical feature of hypophosphatemic rickets. Although serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is increased, this can also be seen in other forms of rickets, but the normal PTH differentiates this condition from others like nutritional rickets and Vitamin D-dependent rickets (VDDR). Additionally, recurrent tooth abscesses and bone deformities, as shown in the image, are typical clinical features of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Additional Information

 

Different type of Rickets:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nutritional rickets: In nutritional rickets, calcium may be normal to low, phosphorus is usually low, and PTH is typically elevated. This is inconsistent with the findings in the current case where PTH is normal.

 

Option C. VDDR 1 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 1): This condition involves a defect in the 1-alpha hydroxylation of Vitamin D, leading to low levels of active Vitamin D. Here, phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, which does not match the patient's normal PTH level.

 

Option D. VDDR 2 (Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2): In this condition, there is end-organ resistance to active Vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), leading to high levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Phosphorus is low, and PTH is elevated, again differing from the normal PTH level observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP). If PTH is normal in a case of suspected rickets, hypophosphatemic rickets should be strongly considered.

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

The developmental milestones are correctly matched as given in option B -1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c.

 

Transfers objects - 6 to 7 months

 

Social smile - 1 to 2 months

 

Pincer grasp - 9 to 12 months

 

Walks 1-2 steps - 12 to 15 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memorize the typical age ranges for key developmental milestones in infants, such as transferring objects, social smiling, pincer grasp, and walking.

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image are:

 

Option A. 1- Rectus femoris

Option B. 2- Vastus lateralis

Option C. 3- Adductor longus

Option D. 4- Sartorius

 

Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '4' is sartorius.

 

The sartorius muscle is a long, thin muscle that runs down the front of the thigh. It is the body's longest muscle and is sometimes referred to as the tailor muscle because of the position that tailors often adopt while working. The sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it, and runs obliquely across the thigh to insert into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity. It joins the aponeurosis of the gracilis and semitendinosus muscles to form the pes anserinus.

 

The sartorius muscle is responsible for several actions, including flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh, as well as flexion of the leg. Because of its location and actions, it is involved in many activities that require movement of the lower limb, such as walking, running, and climbing stairs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)
